name: Maristan
theoryOfChange: Reviving the Islamic legacy of Maristans by integrating Islamic principles (Ilm al-Nafs) with evidence-based mental health practices to provide culturally congruent care and education.

evaluationSources: Stanford Muslim Mental Health & Islamic Psychology Lab (Research Partner)

ui_signals_v1.recommendation_rationale: Limited match due to weaker results and/or higher uncertainty; review methodology details before deciding.

components.evidence: Accepts zakat (+2); Muslim-focused organization (+2); Asnaf: masakin (+5); Humanitarian service (+2)
components.improvement_suggestion: Clarify zakat allocation policy and eligible use categories for donors.
components.name: Muslim Donor Fit

components.improvement_suggestion: Expand services to underserved populations or geographies with limited nonprofit coverage.
components.name: Underserved Space

alignment.rationale: Alignment 31/50: MEDIUM Muslim donor fit, global health cause area

components.improvement_suggestion: Publish beneficiary counts consistently so cost-effectiveness can be assessed.
components.name: Cost Per Beneficiary

components.improvement_suggestion: If reserves are above policy target, document why and publish triggers for planned deployment.

components.improvement_suggestion: Document a clear theory of change with an explicit causal pathway.

score_details.score_summary: Maristan shows good alignment and moderate impact, with zakat compliance (minor risk deductions applied).

all_citations.claim: Maristan focuses on community mental health and holds 13.3 months of working capital.
The organization reported total revenue of $618,632 and a fundraising efficiency of $0.11 per $1 raised.
Maristan operates the Maristan Clinic and provides education and training programs.
The organization is Zakat-eligible and offers specific donation options for donors.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: Maristan earns a moderate score of 49/100, reflecting a balance between strong financial efficiency and a need for greater data transparency and impact verification.
areas_for_improvement: Low data confidence due to limited third-party verification
Need for more transparent reporting on program expense ratios

dimension_explanations.alignment: With an alignment score of 31/50, Maristan shows a medium fit for donors interested in global health and mental health advocacy [1]. The organization is verified as Zakat-eligible, providing a specific giving pathway for Muslim donors [4].
dimension_explanations.impact: The organization focuses on capacity building through its clinical services and training initiatives [3]. While it maintains a healthy 13.3 months of working capital, the overall impact score of 23/50 reflects a medium level of evidence regarding specific cost-per-beneficiary outcomes [1][2].

baseline_narrative.headline: Maristan is a community mental health organization dedicated to providing culturally sensitive clinical care and professional education.
strengths: Strong fundraising efficiency with only $0.11 spent per $1 raised
Robust liquidity with 13.3 months of working capital available
Designated as Zakat-eligible for Muslim donors
baseline_narrative.summary: Maristan operates the Maristan Clinic and various education and training programs to address global health needs through community-based mental health services [1][3]. In the 2023 fiscal year, the organization reported a total revenue of $618,632 [2].

rich_narrative.amal_score_rationale: Maristan earns a moderate score of 49/100, reflecting a balance between strong financial efficiency and a need for greater data transparency and impact verification.

areas_for_improvement.context: The organization currently operates with a <cite id="[2]">board of only 1 member</cite>, which presents significant governance risks.
There is <cite id="[1]">insufficient data for cost-per-beneficiary calculation</cite> and the program expense ratio is missing.

case_against.mitigation_notes: The organization is relatively young (founded around 2022) and is likely still developing its institutional infrastructure.
risk_factors: <cite id="[1]">Financial data for expense breakdown is limited</cite>
case_against.summary: The primary concerns revolve around governance and financial transparency. The organization has a <cite id="[2]">board of only 1 member</cite> and <cite id="[1]">missing program expense ratio data</cite>.

confidence.notes: Data confidence is LOW due to limited transparency and a board size of 1.

alignment.explanation: The alignment score of 31/50 reflects a MEDIUM Muslim donor fit, as the organization operates in the global health space and is <cite id="[4]">designated as Zakat-eligible</cite>.
alignment.improvement: Clarify zakat allocation policy and eligible use categories for donors.

credibility.explanation: Data confidence is LOW (0.19). Donors should be aware of limited data availability, as the organization has <cite id="[2]">only 1 board member</cite> and lacks comprehensive third-party verification.
credibility.improvement: To strengthen credibility, the charity must expand its board of directors to ensure independent oversight and publish audited financial statements.

impact.explanation: The impact score of 23/50 is constrained because <cite id="[1]">financial data for expense breakdown is limited</cite>, making it impossible to calculate a program expense ratio or cost-per-beneficiary.
impact.improvement: Publish beneficiary counts consistently so cost-effectiveness can be assessed, and provide a clear breakdown of program expenses.

donor_fit_matrix.evidence_rigor: Grade C - Some outcome tracking but missing cost data

rich_narrative.headline: Maristan is a community mental health organization dedicated to providing culturally sensitive clinical care and professional education.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who want to support emerging, culturally sensitive mental health services for Muslims in the US and are comfortable with early-stage organizations that lack comprehensive financial data.
donor_motivations: Care deeply about mental health access in the Muslim community
Want to support domestic US initiatives
Comfortable funding early-stage, rapidly growing organizations
giving_considerations: Organization has very limited governance with only 1 board member
Financial breakdown is incomplete, so exact program efficiency is unknown
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors who require rigorous academic evidence of effectiveness, established governance structures, or complete financial transparency.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade C means some outcome measurement exists, but there is insufficient data for cost-per-beneficiary calculation.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: Provides community mental health services and education to improve psychological flexibility and reduce unsafe behaviors.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence helps ensure donations create real impact, especially in clinical mental health settings.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: Rapid revenue growth suggests the organization is actively scaling its services.

peer_comparison.differentiator: Focuses specifically on culturally sensitive Muslim mental health in the USA.

strengths.detail: The organization is highly effective at raising funds, spending only <cite id="[1]">$0.11 per $1 raised</cite>.
Maristan has shown significant financial expansion with a <cite id="[2]">3-Year Revenue CAGR of 376.0%</cite>.
The organization's programs are <cite id="[4]">designated as Zakat-eligible</cite> for Muslim donors.

strengths_deep_dive: Maristan's financial trajectory indicates strong community support and rapid scaling. The <cite id="[2]">3-Year Revenue CAGR of 376.0%</cite> highlights its transition from an early-stage initiative to a growing community resource. Furthermore, its ability to maintain a fundraising efficiency of <cite id="[1]">$0.11 per $1 raised</cite> suggests that the majority of new funding can be directed toward its core mission, despite the current lack of detailed program expense reporting.
rich_narrative.summary: Maristan is a community mental health organization dedicated to providing culturally sensitive clinical care and professional education in the USA. The organization reported <cite id="[2]">$618,632 in total revenue</cite> for the 2023 fiscal year. Maristan demonstrates strong fundraising efficiency, spending just <cite id="[1]">$0.11 per $1 raised</cite>. The charity has experienced rapid growth, with a <cite id="[2]">3-Year Revenue CAGR of 376.0%</cite>. However, financial data for expense breakdown is limited, and the organization currently operates with a <cite id="[2]">board of only 1 member</cite>, which impacts its overall data confidence and credibility scores.
